summary: This document is a draft protocol for the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, established to compensate victims of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein. It outlines the program's purpose, eligibility criteria, claims submission process, evaluation factors, and confidentiality provisions. The program is administered independently by Jordana H. Feldman, with Kenneth R. Feinberg and Camille S. Biros involved in its design.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The document establishes a compensation program for victims of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein. His estate is funding the program.

persons.name: Kenneth R. Feinberg
persons.context: Retained by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to help design the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

persons.name: Camille S. Biros
persons.context: Retained by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to help design the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

persons.name: Jordana H. Feldman
persons.role: Administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program
persons.context: Serves as the Administrator of the Program, responsible for all decisions relating to the review, processing, and evaluation of individual claims. She has final authority on eligibility and compensation amounts.

connections.description: Both were retained by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to design the Victims' Compensation Program.
Both were retained by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to design the Victims' Compensation Program.
Feldman is the Administrator of the compensation program funded by Epstein's estate, but operates independently from it.

events.title: Draft Protocol Release
events.description: Draft of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program Protocol is created, outlining the framework for compensating victims.

locations: Superior Court of the U.S. Virgin Islands
keyFacts: The Epstein Victims' Compensation Program is a voluntary, independent program established to compensate victims of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein.
The program is administered by Jordana H. Feldman, who has final and exclusive authority to determine claimant eligibility and compensation amounts, independent of Epstein's estate.
The program has no cap on the total funds available or on individual compensation amounts.
Eligibility extends to victims regardless of when or where the abuse occurred, whether the claim is time-barred, or if they previously settled with Epstein.
Individuals who allegedly assisted Epstein in procuring victims may be eligible if they acted under duress due to their own abuse by him.
